entry.title: This Is the Way: Rethinking Analytics Orchestration with REST in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Datasphere Task Chains have recently been enhanced with a new capability: the ability to add a REST API Step, as documented by SAP. This addition significantly expands the integration potential of Task Chains, allowing them to trigger or interact with external systems via REST APIs‚Äîsomething previously not possible within the task chain framework itself.

While SAP Datasphere already offers a Command Line Interface (CLI) for interacting with its environment, I believe that technical automation‚Äîespecially triggering Task Chains‚Äîshould be handled via REST endpoints wherever possible. (Yes, I am aware this is already on the roadmap.)

If you have followed the evolution of SAP Analytics Cloud, you have likely noticed how its REST API capabilities have grown considerably. This trend strongly suggests a broader strategic shift within SAP toward more API-driven architectures.
Beyond the technical implications, this new feature offers a glimpse into how future data and analytics architectures might be designed. The ability to call external REST APIs directly from within a Task Chain is a small yet significant change‚Äîit paves the way for loosely coupled, event-driven, and more modular system landscapes.

In this blog post, I will explore the broader implications of this feature‚Äîlooking at both architectural perspectives and practical use cases‚Äîto illustrate how this seemingly simple addition might shape our thinking on modern data platform design going forward. The different implications and perspectives I will try to sketch out in this blog post.

Integration Perspective

With this new capability, you can invoke a REST service directly within a process step. What could such a REST service do? Here are a few examples:

  1. Microservices and Third-Party Data Sources - Trigger a microservice that extracts data from a third-party system and writes it into SAP Datasphere using the OPEN SQL schema.
  2.  Advanced Analytics on External Buckets - Initiate a predictive analytics process after data has been pushed to an external storage location (e.g., a Google Cloud Storage bucket), leveraging external computation power or models.
  3. Endless Possibilities - from orchestrating workflows to enriching data pipelines with external intelligence.

This simple yet powerful feature drastically lowers the barrier for integrating external systems. Especially in modern, heterogeneous IT landscapes, the ability to seamlessly interact with REST services is crucial. As solutions increasingly span multiple platforms and technologies, having native support for REST APIs within Task Chains enables more modular, scalable, and interoperable architectures.

SAC Seamless Planning Perspective

At present, Seamless Planning in SAP provides only a foundational set of features. However, even with these basic capabilities, it is now possible to trigger a Multi Action in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)‚Äîwith some lightweight technical implementation, such as a microservice on SAP BTP to handle user propagation.

What Does This Enable?

It opens the door to scheduling planning-related actions that can be executed automatically‚Äîdaily, during off-peak hours, or at custom intervals‚Äîall orchestrated directly from SAP Datasphere. This marks a significant step toward greater automation and operational efficiency in planning processes.

Looking ahead, the possibility of triggering a Task Chain from within a Multi Action (either via SAP‚Äôs upcoming official Task Chain Trigger feature or through a custom-built solution) would close the loop, enabling bi-directional process orchestration between SAC and Datasphere.

A Vision of Integration - Imagine this scenario:

  • Master data is loaded from an S/4HANA system into Datasphere (where the Master data may be managed in the future) and updated in the planning model.
  • Once this loading process is completed, a Data Action is automatically triggered to generate the necessary planning combinations.
  • Each step is orchestrated across systems‚Äîseamlessly integrating Datasphere and SAC.

This evolving capability points to a promising future, where SAP‚Äôs tools are moving toward more open, event-driven, and tightly connected architectures. It is a strong signal of the direction SAP is heading‚Äîtoward building truly integrated, cross-platform planning and data ecosystems.

Process Orchestration

As outlined in the sections above, these new capabilities significantly enhance our ability to orchestrate analytics processes‚Äîin ways that were not possible just a few weeks ago. The integration of REST API steps and the evolving connectivity between SAP Datasphere and SAC unlocks a new level of flexibility.

What makes this particularly compelling is the ease with which we can now develop lightweight microservices on SAP BTP to support and extend these interactions. Whether it is handling authentication, user propagation, or orchestrating complex logic between systems, BTP provides a robust platform for embedding custom logic into an increasingly modular and responsive analytics architecture.

The On-Premises Thoughts

I have already referred several times to the concept of a ‚Äúsmall microservice on SAP BTP.‚Äù This idea becomes especially relevant when you consider that SAP Datasphere is still often used alongside SAP BW, where orchestration tasks are traditionally handled via Process Chains and ABAP reports.

In many discussions‚Äîwhether with internal teams or external consultants‚Äîthere remains a strong inclination to implement logic directly within the ABAP stack of on-premise systems. This is understandable. It is what I would call the ‚Äúhome-field advantage‚Äù: familiarity, confidence, and reliability in an environment they know well. They‚Äôre certain it will work‚Äîbut the question we must ask is: Will this remain a sustainable approach over the next 5 to 10 years?

The reality is that, SAP‚Äôs Business Data Cloud is on the rise, and the centrality of BW in analytics architectures is gradually diminishing. So why not embrace a more future proof approach?

By building a lightweight REST service on SAP BTP, we gain a flexible, scalable solution that can be triggered both by SAP BW and SAP Datasphere. This doesn‚Äôt just modernize our architecture‚Äîit lays the groundwork for future-proof integration patterns, better modularity, and easier maintenance in a cloud-centric world.

A broader architectural perspective

Another powerful dimension of this development is the ability to interact with a broader range of services available on SAP BTP, such as SAP Event Mesh. For example, you could emit an event to a queue and have that event trigger specific reactions among subscribed services. This pattern‚Äîsimilar to what has long been possible in SAP Data Intelligence using simple Pub/Sub mechanisms‚Äîenables a much cleaner, event-driven architecture that is better aligned with modern cloud-native design principles.

But this blog is not just about the ‚Äúsmall‚Äù new feature of the REST API step. It is about what this feature represents: a clear signal of how the SAP Analytics ecosystem is rapidly evolving toward the Business Data Cloud‚Äîwith SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks at its core (leaving SAP BW Private Cloud Edition aside for now).

This shift demands a mindset change for analytics consultants. To remain relevant and deliver robust solutions, we must go beyond our comfort zones and understand how SAP BTP enriches this ecosystem. That includes learning how to build with CAP or UI5, orchestrate processes using SAP Build, and embrace loosely coupled, service-based thinking.

It‚Äôs no longer just about reporting and data modeling‚Äîit's about understanding how to leverage the entire BTP toolset to design smarter, more flexible processes that are fit for the future.

Conclusion

The REST API step in SAP Datasphere Task Chains is much more than a technical enhancement‚Äîit is a strategic inflection point. It pushes SAP architecture toward:

  • Greater openness and interoperability
  • Microservice- and event-driven thinking
  • Tighter orchestration between SAC, Datasphere, and BTP
  • A cleaner transition from legacy on-prem ABAP logic

The future is modular, cloud-native, and integrated‚Äîand this is your chance to start designing for it.

entry.title: Re: rule to generate Offboarding program by responsibilit...
entry.content:
Hi @mohammadshoaib 

To generate offboarding tasks for assets across your legal entities such as Finance or Admin, SAP recommends you take the following approach:

  • You should set up a ‚ÄúSelect Offboarding Task Config‚Äù rule in your admin center, with explicit ‚Äúif/else rules for every legal entity and responsibility group.
  • After that, create offboarding task Configurations for each group mentioned above in every legal entity, assign desired tasks to the relevant Responsible Group.
  • Follow up with confirming that each group has been assigned the appropriate role permissions to ensure they can access and complete the designated tasks.
  • Finally test these with sample offboarding scenarios and ensure to adjust rules or permissions as desired. Please take note that some tasks might still not generate, if this happens, verify that each If/Else branch is present, groups have permissions, and assignees are properly set.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP
entry.content:
Hi Patrick

let me, as the Developer behind Kernseife, answer this:
Unfortunatly it is not possible to use Kernseife in in ABAP BTP (I guess, that's what you mean by ABAP Cloud).
The Standard Check we are based on and related objects are not C1 ABAP Cloud released. (and yes, we are aware that it is kinda ironic that a Clean Core Tool is not fully Clean Core compliant :))
In ABAP Cloud there is a new framework to build ATC Checks with released classes and interfaces, but those have limitations which make it impossible for us to implement Kernseife in it (which is "proven" by the fact, that also the Standard ATC Check for Usage APIs is not using them).
We would be really happy to bring Kernseife to ABAP BTP, as its role/usage as a Central ATC Check Instance is really nice, but unfortunatly at the moment this is not possible.

Regarding to your exemption questions, I'm not sure if I understand it properly.
Yes, you can run the check on a specific object (e.g. Class) and only get findings inside that class.
Exemptions are possible on 3 Levels (Package, Object and Finding), that is all ATC standard functionality.
But you can't exempt the usage of one object (e.g. Exempt Usage of a FUNC whereever it is used).
That's were you can change the classificatfion in Kernseife and have it rated differently so there are no Prio 1/2 findings anymore.
Kernseife is only checking the "usage" of Objects.
If you mean, if we can use Kernseife Classifications to also allow ABAP Language stuff based on objects, no, that is not possible as this is a different check. Not sure what the Intention would be behind that?

Regards,
Daniel

entry.title: Breaking Free from Legacy Distribution: How SAP SDM Delivers 90% Business Coverage Out-of-the-Box
entry.content:
Breaking Free from Legacy Distribution: How SAP SDM Delivers 90% Business Coverage Out-of-the-Box



Your secondary distribution operations face mounting pressure. Manual dispatch coordination consumes valuable time while delivery schedules struggle to adapt to changing demands. Legacy systems require extensive customizations that compromise SAP upgrades and inflate IT costs. Route planning relies on experience rather than optimization algorithms, leading to suboptimal fuel consumption and vehicle utilization. 

The oil and gas industry demands better solutions. Modern distribution networks require real-time visibility, automated decision-making, and seamless integration with existing SAP infrastructure. Traditional approaches of building custom solutions or heavily modifying core SAP functionality create technical debt that becomes increasingly expensive to maintain.

SAP SDM: Purpose-Built for Downstream and BULK logistics 

SAP SDM (S4SCSD) , developed by Implico  as part of SAP S/4HANA Supply Chain for Secondary Distribution, addresses the specific requirements of oil and gas secondary distribution. The solution covers approximately 90% of best practice business processes out of the box, significantly reducing implementation effort and operational costs. 

SDM operates within SAP's Business Technology Platform architecture, maintaining clean core principles while delivering industry-specific functionality. This approach eliminates the traditional trade-off between operational capability and system maintainability that has plagued oil companies for years. 

Automated Dispatch Management 

The system automates dispatch planning by evaluating customer orders, inventory positions, vehicle capacity, and delivery constraints. Dispatch teams can generate optimized schedules in minutes rather than hours, with the system considering factors such as product compatibility, regulatory requirements, and driver availability. 

Compartment planning functionality optimizes vehicle loading by analyzing product specifications, contamination risks, and cleaning requirements. The system maximizes vehicle utilization while ensuring product integrity and regulatory compliance. 

Intelligent Route Optimization 

SDM incorporates advanced routing algorithms that consider traffic patterns, delivery windows, vehicle specifications, and driver regulations. The system creates routes that minimize transportation costs while maintaining service levels. Integration with GPS and telematics systems provides real-time delivery tracking and enables proactive customer communication. 

When disruptions occur, the system automatically recalculates optimal routes and updates stakeholders. This capability reduces the manual effort required for exception management while improving customer satisfaction. 

Clean Core Implementation Benefits 

SDM's product architecture preserves your SAP clean core strategy. The solution is based on best practice processes and requires no modifications to standard SAP functionality, ensuring smooth upgrades and reduced maintenance overhead.  

Customer-specific requirements can be solved using SAP in-app or side by side extensibilities without modifying the standard code. Your IT organization gains powerful downstream capabilities without compromising system stability or long-term flexibility. 

Implementation typically requires 3-6 months compared to 12-18 months for traditional custom development approaches. Pre-configured integration points for terminal automation, tank gauging, and laboratory systems eliminate common integration challenges that extend project timelines. 

Measurable Business Impact 

Organizations implementing SDM report implementation cost reductions of 40-60% compared to custom development. Operational improvements include dispatch planning time reductions of 70%, improved on-time delivery performance, and decreased safety stock level through better demand forecasting. 

The solution includes built-in compliance frameworks for transportation, environmental, and safety regulations. A capability that reduces manual oversight requirements while ensuring adherence to industry standards. 

Demand Forecasting and Distribution Planning 

SDM analyzes historical consumption patterns, seasonal variations, and market trends to generate accurate demand forecasts. The system considers inventory availability, supplier lead times, and customer requirements to optimize distribution planning. This functionality reduces stockouts while minimizing inventory carrying costs. 

Sales order automation streamlines the creation of quotations, orders, and invoices. The system integrates with customer portals and mobile applications to provide self-service capabilities that reduce administrative overhead. 

Implico Partnership Advantage 

Implico brings four decades of experience in liquid goods distribution and oil and gas retail operations. Their specialized knowledge ensures SDM addresses real-world operational challenges rather than theoretical requirements. The company's holistic consulting approach includes business process optimization, change management, and comprehensive knowledge transfer. 

Implico's quality assurance program provides structured implementation methodology that minimizes project risk. Their team understands the complexities of oil and gas and liquid management  operations and can navigate the unique challenges that arise during system deployment. 

Strategic Implementation Considerations 

SDM enables oil and gas companies to modernize distribution operations without disrupting core SAP functionality. The solution provides immediate operational benefits while maintaining long-term system flexibility. Pre-configured processes address the majority of secondary distribution requirements, allowing your team to focus on optimization rather than basic functionality development. 

Market conditions and regulatory pressures require efficient distribution operations. SDM provides the technology foundation to compete effectively while managing costs. The solution's industry-specific design eliminates the compromises typically required when adapting generic supply chain tools to oil and gas operations. 

Your distribution network can benefit from intelligent automation and real-time visibility. SDM delivers these capabilities through proven SAP technology while maintaining the clean core principles essential for long-term success. 
 
For more information about how SAP SDM can optimize your secondary distribution operations while maintaining clean core architecture, contact Implico to discuss your specific requirements and implementation approach.

entry.title: Re: Mass deletion of MARD entries for a specific storage...
entry.content:
SAP Note 543279 (‚ÄúMM_MATNR: Execution for Specific Organizational Levels‚Äù) extends the standard MM_MATNR archive object by adding organizational‚Äêlevel selection fields‚Äîsuch as plant, storage location, sales organization, distribution channel, warehouse, and storage type‚Äîto the archive write program‚Äôs selection screen. This enhancement lets you zero in on exactly the segments you want to archive, rather than processing all flagged materials across every organizational unit.

In short, how the above note helps to narrow archiving scope is

  • Adds storage location as a filter field on the MM_MATNR archiving variant.
  • Ensures only those materials flagged for deletion at that storage location are picked up.
  • Lets you leave deletion flags in other storage locations untouched, so only your external warehouse entries get archived.

Implementing the note means your MM71/MMREO050 run can target MARD records for a single storage location, reducing collateral deletion risk.

Key Considerations & Limitations

  • The note only enhances the selection screen; it does not change the underlying deletion logic of the MM_MATNR object. If dependencies exist (open POs, reservations, stock, etc.), those records will still be skipped by standard checks.
  • Archiving still operates on the material‚Äêmaster hierarchy: even with a storage location filter, the object processes the material at plant level under the hood. You need to verify that MARD segments get cleaned independently of MARC/MARA.
  • Applying OSS notes requires system preparation (SNOTE download, counterparts, transport, and testing).
  • Extensive testing in a non‚Äêproduction environment is critical to confirm that only the intended MARD entries are actually archived and physically deleted.

With the above, one questions comes to your mind; that is "Is it a viable solution". The answer is Yes if your primary goal is to archive/delete only the storage location segment (MARD) for one warehouse, Note 543279 is a legitimate way to fine‚Äêtune the MM_MATNR archiving selection. It‚Äôs fully SAP-supported and much safer than direct‚Äêtable deletes. However, because it doesn‚Äôt alter the archiving logic itself, you must:

  • Flag your target MARD entries (via MM17/MASS or a custom ABAP).
  • Apply Note 543279 to your archive variant to include storage location as a selection parameter.
  • Run MM71/MMREO050 in test mode first to ensure only those MARD rows are processed.
  • Review logs for skipped records due to dependencies before moving to a productive run.

entry.title: Re: How can we create a UI DEEP link for a Custom Non Use...
entry.content:
Hi @Ayaz 

Thank you for your question.

SAP‚Äôs official help and KBAs for SuccessFactors Public Cloud confirms that it is not currently possible to deep link directly to a custom UI for a non-user-based custom MDF object. The deep link functionality only supports navigation to the standard Manage Data screen or People Profile block if configured for user objects.

SAP recommends linking to the Manage Data screen for your custom object or exposing the relevant access on the SuccessFactors Home Page via portlets. Please note, this will not open your custom UI screen. If you require direct deep links to a custom form or UI, the best approach is to submit an enhancement request to SAP.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

Linking to custom MDF objects

entry.title: Re: IN KE5Z REPORT KRW IS NOT REPORTING CORRECTLY
entry.content:
FI uses table TCURX (transaction OY04) to determine how many decimals each currency has.   For KRW, SAP delivers zero decimals. Controlling (PCA) also reads TCURX‚Äîbut then applies its own scaling when displaying line items via KE5Z. If TCURX has a stray entry for KRW set to ‚Äú2‚Äù decimals, KPI in PCA will multiply your 82 million by 10^2 ‚Üí 8.2 billion.

What you need to do is Run OY04 ‚Üí search for currency KRW ‚Üí ensure Decimal places = 0 (no entry = default 2; explicit 0 = zero). Synchronize TCURX between your FI and controlling clients; transport the correct entry.

In SPRO under Controlling ‚Üí Profit Center Accounting ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Currencies, you define which currency types (0 = local, 1 = group, etc.) PCA reports on. If your controlling‚Äêarea currency type for ‚ÄúLocal Currency‚Äù has been inadvertently set to use a 2-decimal precision, KE5Z will scale up by 10^2.
So go to SPRO ‚Üí Controlling ‚Üí Profit Center Accounting ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Currencies. Verify 0-decimal precision for the ‚ÄúLocal Currency‚Äù entry of your controlling area. Transport and re‚Äêexecute KE5Z.

KE5Z allows you to define scale factors (units, thousands, millions) per report variant in customizing. A variant configured with ‚ÄúScale = 100‚Äù or ‚ÄúDigits = 2‚Äù will multiply all displayed values by 100. So go to SPRO ‚Üí Controlling ‚Üí Profit Center Accounting ‚Üí Information System ‚Üí Reports ‚Üí Line Item Reports ‚Üí Define Scaling Factors. Find the variant used by KE5Z ‚Üí ensure Scale Factor = 1 (no scaling). Re‚Äêrun KE5Z with the corrected variant.

On the KE5Z selection screen, you choose a Currency Type (Document, Local, Group). Selecting ‚ÄúGroup Currency‚Äù can introduce unexpected decimal handling if your group currency differs. On your KE5Z screen, set Currency Type = 0 (Local Currency), Confirm the Currency Code = KRW and execute and compare to RAABGA01.

This is only allowed on a SAP server. So you would need any SAP onPremise system that contains SAPUI5 to run your app in an offline network.

entry.content: @NagaSiva  might this be a problem with the Destination for the BPA? I would to encourage you to check your URLs there

entry.title: Re: 2025 Q3 SAP Analytics Cloud compass Highlights
entry.content:
Hi expert, 
I'm new to the Compass. I also research and understand the concept of Monte Carlo simulation. But the question is: If I have a probability, then what to do next? For instance, the Profit is calculated by Profit = Revenue - COGS - Discount, the target for my Profit is 9M and the probability generated by Compass is 55%, so how can I choose Revenue, COGS and Discount for my planning to achieve the target?
Hope you a nice workng day!
Regards,
Hieu Nguyen

Currently Im trying to implement the Indbound delivery as SOAP API SAP_COM_0224. 

 

sap-vdm-sot-InboundDelivery-v1

 

https://api.sap.com/api/DELIVERYREQUEST_IN/overview

 

When trying to Create a Inbound delivery using the Tool SOAP UI i always get Tons of Error messages like "Authorizationd denied" and "Wrong SOAP Version" 

 

At this moment i did try it all. SOAP V1.1, SOAP 1.2 with there according SAOP envelopes. 

 

This is our endpoint: https://myXXXXXX-api.s4hana.cloud.sap/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/deliveryrequest_in?MessageId=916C6E5X-3BB2-11CA-A054-08002B1BB6K9

entry.title: Re: Issue with assignment of right Inspection Plan to Lot
entry.content:
Hi,

Looks like your setup should work, but maybe check some data in the header: usage & status, the validity dates of the group number plans, the lot size of the group number plans, if the material-vendors combination is assigned to the different group number plans. Assume that the DMR criteria in the plan & quality levels will be per material & vendor (to check per vendor which receipts need to be inspected) and not per manufacturer.

greetings, Herman

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ALM: requirement approval with external workflow management system
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: Fixing Headers & Footers while generating Documents i...
entry.content:
Hi @hiren_6374 

Thank you for raising this issue.

Please note that the Employee Central Document Generation does not currently support fixed headers and footers on every page of a multi-page letter. When a document's content changes or expands, the system may move headers and footers from their intended positions due to the way page breaks are designed or implemented.

However, it is recommended to embed headers or footers as images at the top and bottom of your template. Note that these will only appear once per document and may not remain at the top or bottom on any other subsequent pages. At the moment, there is no configuration or scripting workaround available for true per page headers or footers in EC Document Generation.

Consider submitting an enhancement request via the SAP Influence portal if this limitation heavily impacts your organisation. Alternatively, you may consider external document generation and upload as a workaround.

2423967 - Header and Footer in Document Generation-EC

Enabling and Updating Header and Footer Fields

Organization-Based Email Notification Header and Footer

I hope this provides more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: RAP: Which Activity (ACTVT) should be used in Access Control for Access Category "Value Help/F4"
entry.content:
Hi all,

in an Authorization Object in ABAP Cloud the Activities are mapped to one of the three Categories "Read", "Write", "Value Help".

The Categories are used in Business catalogs (where "Value Help" is labeled as "F4"), Role/Role Template Assignments, etc.

For Activities there are standard values (see eg onpremise in tables acl_actvt/acl_actvtt): 01 for Create, 02 for Change, 03 for Display, 08 for Delete

03 maps to Access Category Read

01,  02, 08 maps to Write

But there is no obvious activity value for Access Category "Value Help".

What activity do you use for Value Help?

Thanks for suggestions, pointers to documentation, tutorials, etc!

Regards,

  Wolfgang

entry.title: Re: How to created claims in BenefitEmployeeClaim via API ?
entry.content:
Hi @rezadwi 

My understanding is that the Benefit Employee Claim object in SAP SuccessFactors is read-only via standard API interfaces. That means it allows only retrieval of claim data but not the creation or update. Employees must submit claims using the Employee Central interface, and claims are then stored in the Benefit Employee Claim object. Please note that there is no supported API endpoint to directly create claims from your inhouse app, nor is there one to store claims in this object programmatically.

For similar automation, you may consider using SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center, custom MDF objects, or certified third-party solutions. However, note that these do not update the standard claim object directly due to system restrictions.

You can submit a business requirement or enhancement request to SAP if direct API-based claim creation into EC Global is a requirement to your organisation.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Global Benefits: A Guided Benefits Enrollment Experience

entry.title: Optimized IDoc Routing in SAP CI with Value Mapping and Groovy-Based Receiver Determination
entry.content:
Target Audience

This blog is primarily intended for the SAP Integration community seeking a strategy for routing outbound IDoc flows from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems‚Äîparticularly for those migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration (Formerly known as SAP Cloud Platform Integration or SAP CPI) and exploring effective alternatives to implement the same.

Motivation

In traditional SAP PI/PO-based landscapes, routing outbound IDocs from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems is straightforward. A single t-RFC destination and IDoc port are typically configured in the sender system to forward all IDocs to SAP PI. Within SAP PI, routing is managed efficiently using the Integration Directory and centralized runtime (AEX), enabling reuse of a single IDoc destination across multiple interfaces and message types (MATMAS, INVOIC, DEBMAS, etc).

However, when migrating to SAP Cloud Integration, this simplicity is disrupted. Cloud Integration does not provide an equivalent mechanism for managing IDoc traffic using a central gateway or common destination. Instead, each interface often requires its own unique endpoint, destination, and port, making the configuration effort redundant and makes IDoc Routing complex  and operationally challenging, as part of this blog I wanted to tackle these challenges and simplify this. (* I wont go into the specific challenges of the different approches and rather focus on the problems I am trying to solve in the current approach)

 

Solution Approach:

As described in the flow above, we will implement the design using two iFlows:

  • IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting:
    This iFlow receives IDoc XML messages from various SAP systems. It is responsible for receiver determination and routes the message to the appropriate target iFlow based on routing logic.
    In SAP PI/PO terminology, this iFlow handles the Inbound Processing and Receiver Determination steps of the integration pipeline.

  • IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>:
    This iFlow is specific to the receiver system and handles transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.
    In SAP PI/PO terms, this iFlow corresponds to the Interface Determination and Outbound Processing steps of the integration pipeline.

IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting

Step 1: Extract Details from EDI_DC40 of IDoc xml and create Exchange properties: 

The IDoc routing in this flow primarily relies on Value Mappings and Groovy scripts. In this step, the necessary inputs and variables are initialized‚Äîthese are later used in Groovy script execution to extract routing details from the configured Value Mappings.

For example, consider a sender system Q10 (the quality environment of the x10 SAP system with client number 001) sending an INVOIC IDoc with an extension type ZINVOIC01. The properties are initialized as below.

                                    

The sentReceiverCount variable is initialized to zero and is later used during processing when the same IDoc meets conditions for multiple receivers, ensuring it is sent to each applicable receiver accordingly.

Step 2: Fetch Receiver List for the IDOC from the Value Mapping tables using Exchange properties:

For this we would need to maintain two value mappings

Value Mapping for Sender Partner Number to Sender Identifier Conversion:

As an example, I have maintained the details of SAP systems x10 and x20 across their Development, Quality, and Production environments. You would similarly maintain all relevant SAP systems and their corresponding identifiers in the Value Mapping used for IDoc routing. This mapping typically requires updates only when new SAP systems are added or existing systems are migrated (when SIDs change), which are relatively infrequent events.

Value Mapping for ReceiverList, Receiver Determination and Receiver Target IFlow URls:

The second Value Mapping is maintained for each unique combination of SAP sender system and IDoc type.
For example, to define receiver determination conditions for the IDOC: INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 sent from the SAP system x10, you would create a corresponding Value Mapping entry as shown below.

The ValueMapping will have 3 Mapping with agency as x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 (sender Identifier.IDOC)

IDOCName to ReceiverList : This mapping holds a list of all receivers applicable for a specific IDoc.

ReceiverName to ReceiverCondition: This defines the receiver determination condition for each receiver. The conditions should be maintained using XPath expressions to evaluate the IDoc content dynamically.

ReceiverName to ReceiverIFlowAddress: This maps each receiver to the endpoint URL of its corresponding integration flow (IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>) , as described earlier in the solution approach.

Now that we've covered how the Value Mappings are maintained, let‚Äôs look at how the Groovy script fetches the appropriate values:

1. Fetch senderIdentifier
The senderIdentifier is retrieved using the exchange property senderPartnerNumber (set in step 1). This value is looked up from the first ValueMapping.
Example:
If a message is sent from system Q10 with sender partner number Q10_001, the senderIdentifier fetched from the Value Mapping would be x10.

2. Construct Agency Key
Using the senderIdentifier and other exchange properties (set in step 1), the agency key is constructed. This key will be used to retrieve routing information from the second ValueMapping.
Agency Format:
<senderIdentifier>.<messageType>.<IDocType>[.<extensionType>]
     senderIdentifier ‚Äì from first Value Mapping
     messageType ‚Äì from exchange property
     IDocType ‚Äì from exchange property
     extensionType ‚Äì from exchange property (optional)
Example:
For an INVOIC IDoc of type INVOIC01 with extension ZINVOIC01 sent from system x10, the agency would be: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01

3. Fetch Receiver List
Using the constructed agency key, the receiver list is retrieved from the second ValueMapping.
Example:
For the agency x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01, the receiver list will be:
Receiver1, Receiver2, Receiver3
Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverList')

Step3: Execute Receiver Determination Conditions (Groovy Script) from Value Mapping

The Groovy script then iterates through the receiver list, fetching the corresponding receiver determination condition for each receiver and evaluating it against the IDoc content using XPath.

// Fetch condition from Value Mapping
currentReceiverCondition = valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverName',
  'Receiver1',
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverCondition'
)
// Evaluate condition
def expr = xpath.compile(currentReceiverCondition as String)
def result = expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.BOOLEAN)

If the condition evaluates to true, the receiver is added to the exchange property determinedReceivers. A counter variable determinedReceiverCount is also maintained to track how many receivers matched successfully.

At the end of this step, three additional exchange properties will be available: determinedReceivers, determinedReceiverCount, and IDOCName (which holds the constructed agency key).

In the example discussed, lets consider if the conditions are satisfied for Receiver2 and Receiver3, then the determinedReceivers list will contain both, and the determinedReceiverCount will be set to 2.
The IDOCName property (i.e., the agency key: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01) is also stored to be reused in subsequent steps of the flow.

Step 4: Send Message to Receiver Specific flow for the  Determined Receivers 

In this step, a looping process call is executed, which repeatedly invokes a local integration process to send the message to each receiver identified in the previous step‚Äîone at a time.

The property sentReceiverCount is incremented after each message is successfully sent to a determined receiver. The loop continues until sentReceiverCount equals determinedReceiverCount, at which point the process terminates.

To send the message to a specific receiver, a Groovy script is used to retrieve the receiver name from the determinedReceivers list. Using this name, the script fetches the endpoint URL of the corresponding receiver-specific iFlow from the second ValueMapping.

Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverIFlowAddress'
)

The fetched endpoint URL is then assigned to the header property receiverProcessDirectURL, which is used by the ProcessDirect adapter to route the message to the appropriate receiver-specific iFlow. IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description> which would handle  transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.

 

Advantages of the Proposed IDoc Routing Strategy in SAP Cloud Integration

 The strategy outlined in this blog offers a scalable, modular, and maintainable alternative that aligns closely with enterprise integration requirements. Below are the key advantages of this design:

1. Reusability of Integration Flows

Instead of creating a separate iFlow for each IDoc-to-receiver combination, this approach separates:
Generic routing logic (IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting)
Receiver-specific logic(IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface>)
Benefit: Reduces development effort and avoids duplication across iFlows, enabling a clean and modular architecture.

2. Centralized Routing with Value Mappings

Routing conditions and receiver lists are managed through Value Mapping artifacts.
Benefit: Updates to routing logic can be done without modifying or redeploying iFlows‚Äîjust update the Value Mapping configuration.

3. Scalable Across Systems and IDoc Variants

Routing logic is built dynamically using:
- Sender system identifier
- Message type
- IDoc type
- (Optional) Extension type
Benefit: Supports complex multi-system, multi-IDoc scenarios without inflating the number of artifacts or flows.

4. Native Support for Multi-Receiver Scenarios

The use of Groovy logic and looping constructs enables routing to multiple receivers based on evaluated XPath conditions.
Benefit: Enables 1:n routing scenarios, ensuring the same IDoc can be routed to multiple receivers without message duplication logic.

5. Low Maintenance and High Adaptability

This architecture requires Value Mapping updates only when:
- New SAP systems are added
- Existing systems are migrated
- Additional receiver conditions are introduced
Benefit: Minimal maintenance effort over time; no need for frequent design or deployment changes.

6. Aligned with SAP PI/PO Routing Model

The flow structure mirrors familiar SAP PI/PO pipeline steps, such as:
- Receiver Determination
- Interface Determination
- Outbound Processing
Benefit: Simplifies migration for teams transitioning from SAP PI/PO to SAP CI, while preserving key routing concepts. Also there is a scope for automation where you could write a code to automate creation of Valuemapping. The existing  ports can be reused by updating the RFC destination pointing to the SAP CI 

This approach attempts to addresses the Technical limitations of SAP CI‚Äôs IDoc handling, and also supports sustainable growth and cleaner and maintainable integration landscapes.

Additional Considerations for Retry and Reprocessing

  1. Retry and error handling should be implemented within each receiver-specific flow to manage failures independently for every receiver.

  2. It is advisable to avoid broadcasting IDocs directly from SAP Cloud Integration, especially in high-volume scenarios like master data distribution across multiple systems. This is due to potential limitations in storing failed messages within the SAP Cloud Integration tenant. Additionally, in broadcast cases, the retry mechanism should support resending only to the receivers where failures occurred, not all recipients.

  3. Exceptions can be returned to the sender system (e.g., via SOAP fault) so that errors are reflected in the originating SAP system(Return Exception to Sender ). This enables visibility in transaction logs like WE02/WE05, helping to identify and reprocess failed IDocs more effectively.

  4. Batch jobs in the SAP backend responsible for reprocessing IDocs should be adjusted based on the new failure status codes introduces by this setup

 

Conclusion

This blog attempted to present a scalable, maintainable, modular and  operationally efficient strategy for receiver determination of outbound IDocs from SAP system by leveraging Groovy script and Value Mapping. Also by decoupling the routing and receiver-specific logic into two separate iFlows, the solution ensures better reusability, easier maintenance, and greater control over message processing.

entry.title: Clean Core by Design: Using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AES) as the First Principle
entry.content:
In the digital era of today where digital transformation is every organization‚Äôs need, SAP Clean Core Principle is more than just a word, it's a among the foundational principle for enterprises looking to future-proof their SAP landscape. As per the SAP clean core approach, where technology is moving towards API first Approach, modular architectures, the organizations must decouple their custom logic instead of the application server to external API‚Äôs outside the application server layer to ensure agility, scalability, and reducing the upgrade complexity.

One of the most powerful enablers of this Clean Core approach is the event driven architecture through SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AES), an enterprise-grade event brokering solution that supports real-time, event-driven architectures across hybrid landscapes.

In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through how to achieve Clean Core by adopting AES as the first principle, laying the groundwork for a decoupled, scalable, and intelligent enterprise.

 The Clean Core Strategy ‚Äî What and Why?

  1. Avoid Extensions where not required
  2. Upgrades should not interfere with the extensions and extensions should not interfere with the upgrades
  3. Decouple the extensions from the Standard
  4. Keep the custom code separate from the S4 Core

A Clean Code

The Clean Core strategy focuses on:

  • Keeping custom code, extensions, and integrations outside the SAP S/4HANA digital core.
  • Leveraging side-by-side extensibility using SAP BTP.
  • Using stable APIs and events to communicate between systems and layers.

This approach ensures that your core ERP remains clean, lean, and easily upgradeable‚Äîan essential factor for reducing TCO and accelerating innovation cycles.

In short, minimize extensions, decouple them from the standard, build side-by-side extensions on the BTP layer without touching the S4 HANA Core.

 Why AES as the First Principle?

To achieve the clean core strategy, event driven architecture plays an important role by decoupling the processes through individual events, following the loosely couple framework and avoiding tightly coupled integrations.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh enables event-driven architecture (EDA) that decouples the source of truth (S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, C4C, etc.) from consumers (external apps, extensions, APIs). Here's why it's foundational to Clean Core:

  • Asynchronous Communication: No tight coupling between systems.
  • Loose Integration: Replace point-to-point interfaces with publish-subscribe models.
  • Extensibility: Let consumers build side-by-side extensions without modifying the core.
  • Scalability: Support multiple consumers with minimal configuration overhead.

 Clean Core in Action ‚Äî Event-Driven Architecture with AES

Let‚Äôs take a simple example: BP Onboarding in SAP S/4.

 Without Clean Core (Tightly Coupled):

  1. Custom ABAP enhancements in S/4HANA to trigger BP Creation/ Change Events.
  2. Direct API calls or IDoc triggers to downstream applications like ARIBA/ C4C/ Hybris/ External Applications from S/4.
  3. Every new consumer or change = new code or regression testing.

 With Clean Core (Using AES):

  1. S/4 HANA triggers the BP Creation Event via Event Enablement Cockpit.
  2. AES captures the events and routes it to all the subscribers.
  3. Subscribers (CPI, CAP apps, external systems) performs the required logic without modifying the core system.

No enhancement. No code in the core. Just events and clean extensions.

Common Use Cases Where AES Drives Clean Core

  • Customer/Vendor Create in S/4HANA ‚Üí Event to AES ‚Üí Update CRM/External apps.
  • Purchase Order Created ‚Üí Event routed via AES ‚Üí Notify suppliers via external systems.
  • Material Master Update ‚Üí Trigger downstream analytics apps or warehouse systems.

 Building Blocks of a Clean Core Event Strategy

1. Enable Eventing in Source System

    • Use Event Enablement Cockpit in S/4HANA (Cloud or Private Edition).

Within the SAP Application layer, where various types of event triggers are captured, these triggers can originate from the standard SAP mechanisms/ processes like Business Objects Repository(BOR) Event, Change Documents (CDHDR/ CDPOS), BTE(Business Transaction Event), IDOC Creation, Output Determination routines, and RAP based Event Triggers.

     

2. Route Event to AES

    • Configure the required events in SAP S/4 to Publish Events to SAP Event Mesh/ AES
    • Do the proper topic configurations and ensure secure connectivity.

3. Integrate with AES

    • Use AMQP 1.0 protocol or SAP Event Mesh/ Advance Event Mesh Adapter in Integration Suite.

  1. Design Reusable Consumers
    • Keep business logic in SAP BTP (CAP, CPI, etc.).
    • Use topic naming standards (e.g., sap/s4/customer/created).

  2. Govern Events
    • Maintain versioning, documentation, and routing rules in AES.


      ‚ÄÉ

 Combine AES with SAP Integration Suite or APIM

AES becomes even more powerful when used alongside SAP Integration Suite:

  • Route events from AES to CPI flows for orchestrations or APIM for Just Routing.
  • Use Process Integration for sync calls only where truly needed.

Practical Use Case:

Connect the S/4 or ERP to Advance Event Mesh (Either via Enterprise Event Enablement or ASAPIO Add-on) and setup the corresponding business events and topic hierarchies in AES,

Go to the Broker Manager of the of the AES,

Setup the Event Configuration via SAP Enterprise Event Enablement in the S/4

1. Create Queue

 

2. Subscribe to the Topic

 

 

3. Advance Event Mesh Subscriber Configuration:


4. Depending on the Design, Processing Configuration Can be Altered


or



or



 

Summary

In SAP S/4 HANA, achieving Clean Core is no longer an optional choice, it‚Äôs a foundational strategy for designing scalable, maintainable, and future ready enterprise landscapes. This blogs explored how the SAP AES empowers the organizations to adopt event driven architecture(EDA) that supports the Clean Core Principle by:

  • Decoupling the Core: Separating the custom logic, integrations, and extensions from the S/4HANA core using publish-subscribe event models.
  • Enabling Side-by-Side Extensibility: Leveraging SAP BTP and AES to develop external applications and microservices without modifying the digital core.
  • Ensuring Upgrade Agility: Keeping the S/4 core untouched allows smooth upgrades with minimal regression testing.
  • Scaling Across Hybrid Landscapes: Distributing business events asynchronously to multiple consumers (on-premises and cloud) with minimal configuration overhead.

 Conclusion

Embracing SAP Advanced Event Mesh as the foundation of your integration and extension strategy ensures that you're not only building for the present, but also for the future. With AES, you unlock a Clean Core architecture that is:

‚úÖUpgradable
‚úÖExtensible
‚úÖDecoupled
‚úÖScalable

The Clean Core is no longer a destination, it‚Äôs a design principle. And AES is your first step on that journey.

entry.title: RAP - With Deep Static Action - OData V4 - Complete Guide till Execution in Gateway
entry.content:
Summary:

In some of SAP RAP (RESTful Application Programming) scenarios, there is a need to pass a request body to an action as input, execute business logic, and return the output in the response body. While SAP RAP offers a "Deep Action" feature to facilitate such requirements, this capability is currently not supported in OData V2.  As a result, developers seeking to implement this pattern must turn to OData V4, which introduces expanded support for complex actions and payload handling.

This blog will walk you through a practical, step-by-step session on how to implement request/response body handling in RAP Actions using OData V4, ensuring you can meet advanced integration and business process needs in your SAP applications. Also this blog explains how to capture your OData V4 service in TR Properly.

The Aim is to create Single Parent Entity and create Deep Action out of it which acts like same OData Deep Entity. 

The Action can be exposed to interface where it can be used for POST Operations. ( GET Can be used only to get CSRF Token for security layer.

Before getting deep dive into RAP Deep Actions, first we need to understand that RAP Actions are generally function imports in OData V2 and in OData V4 it shows as Action itself in Meta Data Extension.

Now let's start with the build.

1) Create Root View Entity

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Test'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZCDS_TEST_PARENT_ENTITY as select from ekko
{
    key ebeln as Ebeln,
    bukrs as Bukrs,
    bsart as Bsart,
    lifnr as Lifnr
}

2) Create Behavior Definition on top of Root View Entity

3) After Creating Behaviour Definition with appropriate Alias and read only properties, Add Static Action with Deep structure as per your requirement. The syntax is as below. ( Note for the deep action you must create Deep Abstract Entity which I will explain in upcoming points ). 

static action TestAction deep parameter ZCDS_ROOT_ABSTRACT_TEST_API deep result[1..*] ZCDS_ROOT_ABSTRACT_TEST_API;

4) While using Deep Action, in Result [1..*] is important which indicates that Action will expand for Deep structure for Result. But for Input cardinality is not required.

5) Create Root Abstract Entity

@EndUserText.label: 'Root Abstract'

define root abstract entity ZCDS_ROOT_ABSTRACT_TEST_API
{
  key Ebeln     : ebeln;
      Bukrs     : bukrs;
      _Parenttochild : composition [1..*] of ZCDS_CHILD_ABSTRACT_TEST_API;
}

 6) Create corresponding child Abstract Entity

@EndUserText.label: 'Child Abstract'
define abstract entity ZCDS_CHILD_ABSTRACT_TEST_API
{
    key Ebeln : ebeln;
    key ebelp : Ebelp;
        Matnr_ae : matnr;
     _ChildtoParent : association to parent zcds_root_abstract_test_api on $projection.ebeln = _childtoParent.ebeln;
    
}

7) Create Abstract - Behavior Definition

abstract;
strict ( 2 );
with hierarchy;

define behavior for ZCDS_ROOT_ABSTRACT_TEST_API //alias <alias_name>
{
  association _Parenttochild;
}

define behavior for ZCDS_CHILD_ABSTRACT_TEST_API //alias <alias_name>
{
}

üòéCreate Respective Service Definition and Service Binding. ( Note Service Binding to be created in OData - V4 Web API for Interface Based Requirements and OData - V4 UI for Fiori/BTP Based Requirements. Currently Im creating OData - V4 Web API since we are testing in gateway only ).

@EndUserText.label: 'Test'
define service ZCDS_TEST_ENTITY_SRV {
  expose ZCDS_TEST_PARENT_ENTITY as TestEntity;
}

9) After creating the service Binding Activate it and publish it. In this Blog we are also going to see how to save/capture V4 OData service in TR Properly.

10) Once Publishing the service, navigate to /n/iwfnd/v4_admin Transaction and find your service Group. Right click on the service and click on Transport Publishing.

11) After clicking on Transport Publishing it will ask for Customizing TR, Save the service in Customizing TR and click on LOCAL system Alias and then select Transport Routing Assignment. It will ask for Customizing TR again and save it in Customizing TR. With these steps your OData V4 Service will get properly captured in TR.

12) After capturing service in TR, click on the Service and select Service Test.

13) As Mentioned above RAP Action's will be considered as Actions in OData V4 whereas in OData V2 it will be taken as Function Imports. Refer to screenshot below for the same which shows the Action we created as Action while loading Meta data.

14) Now let's construct URL and Payload for OData V4 RAP Action.

URL Format : 

"1" : /sap/opu/odata4/sap/zcds_test_entity_srv/....

"2": TestEntity/

"3": com.sap.gateway.srvd_...

"4": .TestAction

Final URL : "1" && "2" && "3" && "4"

In simple Terms the "1" will be coming by default once you enter the gateway and "2" will be also coming by default once you add the entity. Then "3" is something which is for OData V4 and it's schema namespace which you will find while loading meta data. Finally "4" is your Action.

URL Should look like this:

/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zcds_test_entity_srv/..../TestEntity/com.sap.gateway.. .TestAction

Note : Action should be exposed with a dot (.)  after Schema Namespace

Payload;

The Payload should hold all properties from Action Parameters. It will not play any crucial role with Root CDS View Entity inputs rather static action will expect all the deep parameters to be passed to initiate POST Operation in Input payload. 

For Our Scenario let's Pass Payload like this.

{
    "Ebeln": "1050001",
    "Bukrs": "001",
    "_Parenttochild": [
        {
            "Ebeln": "1050001",
            "Matnr": "000000000000000001"
        }
    ]
}

15) After passing the payload, we often do get this error while execution which is Authorization block. To resolve this we have to get appropriate authorization from BASIS for Auth objects; S_START and S_SERVICE.

 

16) Once Necessary Authorization is obtained we do get response like this in Deep structure in Response body.

17) Henceforth with this way we can use Deep Action and pass input in Body instead of payload as deep structure. This could be used for Interface as well as Fiori based objects. In Fiori with same way the testing can be done in Fiori Launchpad with deployed app with Action button having deep structure. 

18) Static Action should hold whatever Business logic is for POST inside RAP Behavior Implementation class. The UI/3rd party system input can be read from keys parameter with appropriate %cid_ref and once all business logic is done the response can be mapped to result parameter of same action.

19) If you want to read some of the CDS View properties then instead of static action you can use normal action also with deep parameters.

20) If the requirement demands to send Deep structure as output only or vise versa means then in this case you can avoid deep structure in either parameter or response as shown below;

static action TestActionDeepInput deep parameter ZCDS_DEEP_ABSTRACT result[1]ZCDS_OUTPUT_ABSTRACT;
static action TestActionDeepOutput parameter ZCDS_INPUT_ABSTRACT deep result[1..*]ZCDS_DEEP_ABSTRACT;

 

Conclusive Summary

I hope this blog has clarified key concepts around OData V4, RAP Deep Actions, Deep Abstraction, and capturing V4 services in a transport request. In future posts, I‚Äôll explore running background jobs with RAP and Application Jobs.
Thank you for reading!

entry.title: Re: How to hide inactive plants from LOV in standard SAP...
entry.content:
Couple of options are there

Option-1 - Restrict via Plant-Level Authorization (S_T001W)
The only standard, non-coding way to prune the F4 list is to limit which plants a user is authorized to see:

  • Object S_T001W (Plant authorizations) controls which WERKS values the user can select.
  • If a plant is not in the user‚Äôs S_T001W profile, it will be omitted from F4 in most SAP GUI transactions.

You can maintain S_T001W by:

  • Creating a copy of each business role in PFCG.
  • In the Authorization tab, add object S_T001W ‚Üí field WERKS ‚Üí assign the subset of active plants.
  • Generate and assign the role.

This approach preserves historical data in T001W but ensures users never even see the inactive plants.


Option-2 - Filter the F4 Help via a Search-Help Exit or BAdI

If you prefer not to manage authorizations per plant, you can enhance the standard search help to exclude LOEVM-flagged entries. Two options:

Implicit Enhancement to the Search Help
In SE11, locate the search help WERKS_SH (the one attached to your plant field). Switch to ‚ÄúExit‚Äù and insert code that reads T001W‚ÄìLOEVM for each candidate row. Skip any row where LOEVM = 'X'.

BAdI DD_SHLP_EXIT

  • Implement method IF_DD_SHLP_EXIT~EXIT in your enhancement implementation.
  • Check if IS_SHLP-ID = 'WERKS_SH'.
  • Loop at CT_VALUES (the F4 result), read T001W‚ÄìLOEVM for each CT_VALUES‚ÄìFIELDVAL, and delete any entries flagged for deletion.

After activating this enhancement, your F4 help will dynamically filter out inactive plants everywhere the WERKS_SH search help is used.

entry.title: Structured address data elements in ISO 20022 messages
entry.content:
Introduction

ISO 20022 includes data elements to capture additional information regarding the parties (entities and persons) involved in the transaction. Each party‚Äôs name and address is defined in a granular structure that distinguishes ‚ÄòName‚Äô and the various components of address ‚Äì ‚ÄòBuilding Number‚Äô, ‚ÄòStreet‚Äô, ‚ÄòTown‚Äô, ‚ÄòCountry‚Äô (code), etc. (see table below). In MT, a name and address are represented by four lines each of 35 characters, either in an unstructured format or with a structure that distinguishes only name, country code, city and other details.

 

Unstructured address version will end on Nov 2025

Due to the coexistence period of both ISO 20022 and MT formats, in cross-border payments, current practices will be accommodated. Until November 2025, ECP usage guidelines allows both, structured and unstructured address, to be used in a mutually exclusive way, i.e., either unstructured address in the ‚ÄòAddress Line‚Äô element or structured address in the dedicated tags can be used

Given that as of November 2025 payments must be initiated using structured ISO 20022 party addresses, this may represent a challenge for the corporates that maintain address data elements of their customers, suppliers and counterparties in an unstructured database

 

Hybrid address version

The hybrid address version is a mix of structured and unstructured address details. It allows the combination of structured ISO 20022 address elements and up to two lines of 70 characters of unstructured ‚ÄúAddress Line‚Äù . Elements available in a structured format must be mapped into the respective structured address elements. The structured elements ‚ÄúCountry‚Äù <Ctry> and ‚ÄúTown Name‚Äù <TwnNm> are mandatory. Content of structured elements cannot be repeated in the <AdrLine> elements.

 

Structured addresses in SAP delivered mappings

 

SAP delivers format mapping templates which implement only the structured address version for formats based on ISO20022‚Äôs 2019 version .

PAIN.001.001.09 and PAIN.008.001.08

All sub-tags of <PstlAdr> are defined* for later use in custom copies as shown on the right side. (*see Activate/deactivate a node on SAP Help portal)

SAP Notes:

  • 2784858 for SAP S/4HANA Private ERP
  • 2253571 for SAP ERP

Please check with your house bank for their specific requirements with regards to Structure/Hybrid address handling.

 

 

Useful Links

EPC Guideline document

Extended Data Medium Exchange Engine (DMEEX)

Payment formats in SAP blog

entry.title: Re: How to prevent billing plan value greater than sales...
entry.content:
In Public Cloud you extend business logic via the Custom Logic ‚Äì Manage Business Add-Ins Fiori app. For sales-order save-time checks, SAP delivers a purpose-built Cloud BAdI: C_SALESORDER_MANAGE_CHECK (Interface IF_C_SALESORDER_MANAGE_CHECK). This is the only supported hook that fires just before the order is committed, and it lets you raise error messages to block a save.

In your Public Cloud tenant, open the Fiori launchpad and find Custom Logic ‚Äì Manage Business Add-Ins. Filter by Application or Business Context ‚ÄúManage Sales Orders‚Äù (or search for ‚ÄúSALESORDER‚Äù). You‚Äôll see the entry C_SALESORDER_MANAGE_CHECK. Create a new implementation, give it a name/description, and click into the check method. Write your validation logic in the guided editor (no ADT/SE19 coding).

Typical steps in your check method:

  • Read the order header + items from the BAdI‚Äôs importing parameters.
  • For each item, call the standard billing-plan API (e.g. service /API_SALESORDERBILLINGPLAN or any published function) to fetch and sum the plan amounts.
  • Compare the sum to the item‚Äôs net-value.
  • If the plan total exceeds net, use the BAdI‚Äôs ADD_MESSAGE API to post an error (message class V4-135).

entry.title: Re: No Proposal for activites in confirmaiton paramters O...
entry.content:
Even if you tick all three boxes under Quantities, Activities and Dates in OPK4, COR6N will pull its settings from the Confirmation Profile, not directly from OPK4.

  • Go to OPK0 (‚ÄúConfirmation Parameters PP‚ÄìProcess Orders‚Äù) or OPK1 (‚ÄúConfirmation Parameters Discrete Mfg‚Äù) depending on your order type.
  • For your Order Type + Plant, set on the Default Values tab: ‚ÅÉ Quantities ‚Üí Immediate Proposal ‚ÅÉ Services (Activities) ‚Üí Immediate Proposal ‚ÅÉ Dates ‚Üí Immediate Proposal
  • Save your profile (e.g. ZCP_PROF01).
  • In SU01 (or SU3), under your user‚Äôs Parameters tab, add: Parameter ID = CORUPROF Parameter Value = your confirmation profile (ZCP_PROF01)

Once assigned, COR6N picks up the profile settings and will propose your activity times.


Your routing‚Äôs Control Key (defined in SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí Basic Data ‚Üí Define Operation Control Keys or in CA02/CA03 on each operation) must allow activity confirmations:

  • Open the control key and ensure ‚ÄúServices‚Äù (SAP jargon for activity-type confirmations) is enabled.
  • If it‚Äôs off, COR6N won‚Äôt even show the ‚ÄúActivity‚Äù column, regardless of your profile settings.

You have to use the Correct Config Transaction

  • OPK0 / OPK1 apply to posting transactions (CO11/CO11N/CO15).
  • OPK4 only drives the display in COR6N when you hit the ‚ÄúActual Data‚Äù button on a process order confirmation.

If you confirm via CO11N/CO15, OPK4 isn‚Äôt used‚Äîyou need OPK0. Conversely, if you‚Äôre purely reviewing in COR6N, OPK4 must mirror the same settings you‚Äôve given OPK0/OPK1, but COR6N still draws from the user‚Äôs CORUPROF profile.

entry.title: Unlocking Business AI value with SAP and Perplexity üöÄ üîç
entry.content:
Hello from the SAP B-Lab team! üëã
We have been tinkering, testing, and pushing the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible by combining SAP‚Äôs rock-solid master-data backbone with the Perplexity API‚Äôs limitless knowledge from across the web.
Imagine having your ERP enriched not just by internal history, but by real-time insights, market signals, and context you never had before.
The result? Faster decisions, fewer data gaps, and a seriously impressive ROI. Ready to dive in? Let‚Äôs go! üí•

1. Smart Master-Data Enrichment: Fill the Gaps Instantly üõ†Ô∏èüí°

When you onboard a new customer or supplier, missing fields are the bane of every data steward‚Äôs existence. By tapping Perplexity‚Äôs API, SAP can:

Auto-populate address verification, corporate hierarchies, and industry codes from trusted online sources.
Suggest contact persons and roles by crawling company websites and social profiles.
Flag inconsistencies in real time, so your team intervenes only when human judgment really matters.

ROI boost: Slash manual data-entry by up to 70%, speed up onboarding by days, and reduce errors that can cost thousands in mis-shipments or compliance penalties.

 

2. Dynamic Supplier Risk Monitoring: Stay Ahead of the Curve ‚ö†Ô∏èüìà

Global supply chains are unpredictable. Combine SAP‚Äôs supplier master data with Perplexity‚Äôs real-time news & market alerts to:

Automatically surface negative press or ESG warnings about a supplier.
Track geopolitical events that might disrupt shipments.
Receive risk-scoring enrichments based on financial health, litigation records, and sentiment analysis.

ROI boost: Proactively switch to safer partners, reduce expedited-shipping costs, and avoid disruption-related penalties.

 

3. Market-Driven Pricing Optimization: Win Every Bid üí∞üèÜ

Pricing strategies need to reflect market realities today, not last quarter. By bringing Perplexity into your procurement cockpit, you can:

Fetch live commodity prices (steel, oil, grain) and factor them into purchase-order simulations.
Benchmark competitor pricing for similar products or services.
Run ‚Äúwhat-if‚Äù cost-impact analyses instantly, with data sourced from vendor websites, trading platforms, and news feeds.

ROI boost: Improve margin by up to 5% through smarter sourcing decisions, and negotiate better contracts with real data at your fingertips.

 

4. Hyper-Personalized Customer Insights: Speak Their Language ü§ùüìä

entry.title: Re: DB2 11.5 LUW - HADR rebuild from online backup ?
entry.content:
Hello Brian,

generally, it is possible to use an online backup to set-up / initialize the HADR standby database.'
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/db2/11.5.x?topic=availability-initializing-hadr

"The general procedure is to take a backup of the primary, restore it to the standby, set various HADR configuration parameters, and then issue the START HADR command. The backup of the primary can be an online backup. "


However, the potential challenge may come with the (remote) catchup phase of the standby and replay of logs. The standby needs to handle both catching up with the logs generated since the backup finished up to the current point in time,  while the primary continues to produce workload which also needs to be replayed. Your standby needs to be capable of handling the workload and be able to catch up faster than the primary generates new logs. This is highly dependent on your specific environment, e.g. the sizing of the HADR standby environment.

I recommend to start building your HADR standby as soon as possible after the backup finished to minimize above mentioned replay and - if possible - use a time of reduced production workload (e.g. a weekend).

Note that above would basically be true for an offline backup, too (unless you stop production during the whole process).

Hope this helps, Hans-Juergen

entry.title: Re: importing employees using optionId
entry.content:
Hi @user116 

Thank you for your question. I will walk you through the possibilities available.

Please note, for fields defined as picklists, you are required to use the internal numeric optionId and not the picklist label in the import file. If you choose to use a label such as "Germany‚Äù the system will not map it correctly and the field will appear blank in the employee profile. That my trigger the Location field to behave differently due to its specific configuration. The standard practice requires optionIds for all picklist fields.

To avoid blanks in the file, please export the picklists to obtain the correct option-Ids and use those in your import file. Also, make sure you remove any commas in optionIds before importing it.

Even if your client does not have Employee Central, the system or integration expects optionId for picklist fields during your import.

I hope this provides more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP B1 10.0 FP 2411 ‚Äì OBTF / Journal Voucher: ONNM.AutoKey (ObjectCode 28) does not increment
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

in SAP Business One 10.0 FP 2411 - MS SQL,  when adding a Journal Voucher (table OBTF), the AutoKey in ONNM for ObjectCode = 28 does not increment by +1 upon completing the operation. As a result, the next insertion attempt reuses the same BatchNum, causing the following error:
‚ÄúThis entry already exists in the following tables ‚ÄòDocument with provisional postings‚Äô (OBTF) (ODBC-2035) [Message 131-183]‚Äù.
The issue is temporarily resolved by manually aligning ONNM.AutoKey or restoring document numbering, but it reoccurs afterwards. 
Can you help  me? 
Thanks in advance. 

Best Regards
